framework_intro.para: Below is a suggested framework to help you structure your CV if you are an experienced candidate applying for a job. There are spaces for you to add notes and the content of your CV.
You can visit the help section to learn more about Oxford iWriter.

commentary.para: A well written, well produced, appropriate CV/curriculum vitae (British English) or résumé (American English) is vital for getting you to the interview stage for a job. This model is an example of how you might structure your CV if you are an experienced candidate applying for a job. This experienced candidate is seeking a senior management position in his field.
Also look at the covering/cover letter.
Below is the framework that was used to create this CV.
The labels, 'Name', Address', etc. can be omitted. There is no need to mention your age, gender, nationality, race, religion or marital status. Don't send a photo unless you are asked to.
This section gives an employer an idea of who you are.

Experienced candidates often describe their skills before giving their employment history. You can make a lot of this section and include organizational, communication, computer, social, and any other skills relevant to the post you are applying for, in separate sections.

This is shown in reverse order, beginning with the most recent. Begin each job with the title and responsibilities and follow with your achievements. More information is given about the most recent post.
These are shown in reverse order and include only key qualifications.

checklist.point: Collect together all the information you need to include in your CV.
Select information that is relevant to the job you are applying for.
Make sure all the information is accurate.
Use action verbs and adjectives to present yourself positively.
Use appropriate vocabulary to describe your skills and experience.
Organize the information into the framework.
Show Work history and Qualifications in reverse order, beginning with the most recent.
Use either full sentences (e.g. I lead a team of 15 geologists) or note form (Lead a team of 15 geologists).
Make the most of all your skills.
Have I kept my CV short? (no more than 2 pages if possible)
Have I used capitals, bold type, spacing and underlining to make my CV attractive and easy to read?
Have I used a typeface such as Times New Roman, Arial or Verdana in at least 10 pt?
Have I used reasonable margins on the page?
Have I checked spelling and punctuation?

paragraph.name: Personal profile
paragraph.tip: TIP You should include this section to give an employer an idea of who you are.

content.para: Personal profile:

An exceptionally well-qualified and experienced oil-industry professional with wide knowledge of surveying techniques in off and on-shore environments. Excellent intercultural and communication skills. A regular conference speaker and part-time university lecturer.

paragraph.name: Skills
paragraph.desc: Experienced candidates often describe their skills before giving their employment history.
paragraph.tip: TIP You can make a lot of this section and include organizational, communication, computer, social, and any other skills relevant to the post you are applying for, in separate sections.

content.prompt: Type details of your skills here
content.para: Management skills:

I have considerable experience of managing and leading large teams of geologists and field workers, planning and organizing research and explorations. This also involves the ability to deal promptly and calmly with problems or emergencies that arise in the field.
I work with the teams coordinating the presentation of the research findings.
Intercultural and communication skills:
I liaise with petroleum companies and government ministries at the highest level, which requires tact, diplomacy and the ability to present a case with clarity and accuracy.

As well as working with colleagues from other parts of the world, I have set up and run successful training programmes for graduate trainees from our sister companies in Kuwait and elsewhere. These are now an established part of the training of new recruits.
I work with postgraduate students of all nationalities at the University of Southampton, giving an annual series of seminars.
I am frequently invited to give papers at conferences.

paragraph.name: Work history and experience
paragraph.desc: This in reverse order, beginning with the most recent.
paragraph.tip: TIP Put this section before your education. Give more information about the most recent post. Begin each job with the title and responsibilities and follow with your achievements. It is not usual to include details of your current salary.

content.prompt: Type details of your experience here
content.para: Work history and experience:

2000-present: Chief geologist HBF exploration. I currently lead a team of 15 geologists and field workers. I deal with all aspects of research, forecasting and presentation of findings. I liaise with petroleum companies and government ministries.
1996-2000: Geologist with Anglo-Dutch Petroleum. I conducted surveys in different environments. I set up a training programme for graduate trainees from sister companies in Kuwait and elsewhere.
1993-1996: Geologist with Aberdeen-based consultancy. I conducted surveys and explorations. I prepared feasibility studies in North Sea fields.
